FacilityName: Carlisle Region Water Pollution Control Facility
ParentCompanyName: Borough of Carlisle Sewer System Authority

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Borough of Carlisle Sewer Authority owns the Carlisle Regional Water Pollution Control Facility, which is operated by the Borough of Carlisle.  The facility's service area is composed of five (5) contributing municipalities, including the Borough of Carlisle, Middlesex Township, North Middleton Township, South Middleton Township, and Silver Spring Township.  The Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP), located at 54 North Middlesex Road in Middlesex Township, Cumberland County, is permitted to process up to 7.0 million gallons per day (mgd) of wastewater as an average annual daily flow and discharges to the Conodoguinet Creek under NPDES Permit No. PA0026077.  The Water Quality Management (WQM) Part II permit 219405 issued November 18, 2009 identified the Maximum Month Design capacity of 9.45 mgd and a Design Organic Capacity of 27,460 lbs/day. Wastewater treatment processes include grit and coarse screenings removal, primary sedimentation, secondary activated sludge treatment, clarification, filtration, and disinfection.  Solid material removed from this process is stabilized using post lime addition, dewatered, and utilized for agricultural purposes through land application.  The plant is operated 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.



The WWTP includes a disinfection system comprised of a chlorine scale room, which contains three (3) one ton containers of chlorine liquefied under pressure, a chlorinator room containing chlorinators, various safety equipment, and instrumentation consisting of automated chlorine and flow recorders, electrical panels, and a gas detector/alarm unit.  Up to three (3) full one ton containers containing chlorine may be on site simultaneously but inside the chlorine builidng. A storage rack for up to four (4) empty containers is located outside the building The automated chlorinator system extracts chlorine gas from the storage containers through remote vacuum regulators and dissolves this gas in water to form a disinfection solution t

e presence of a chlorine gas detector.



Based on available data, no accidental releases of chlorine have occurred at this facility in the past 5 years.



    The facility has an emergency response program that has been reviewed and coordinated by the Cumberland County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) in Carlisle.  The operation and response procedures are reviewed and updated on an a frequent basis by the Cumberland County LEPC.  The Cumberland County Defensive Hazardous Materials (HAZMAT) Response Team is the designated first-responder in the event of a chlorine leak incident.  This HAZMAT team is state certified and undergoes extensive training in dealing with a variety of hazardous material incidents, including chlorine gas leaks.  



Recommendations to improve safety were made following a April 24, 2014, 2009 inspection of the disinfection system by the Borough's Consulting Engineer.  These recommendations included periodic review to non-emergency standard operating procedures (SOPs) , review of the operator training program, and increased documentation of routine functions related to the performance of the two regulated processes.
